resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
liyafan82 commented on pull request #5944: ARROW-7301: [Java] Sql type DATE should correspond to DateDayVector
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5944
 
 
   According to SQL convertion, sql type DATE should correspond to a format of YYYY-MM-DD, without the components for hour/minute/second/millis
   
   Therefore, JDBC type DATE should correspond to DateDayVector, with a type width of 4, instead of 8.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

walterddr commented on pull request #5944: ARROW-7301: [Java] Sql type DATE should correspond to DateDayVector
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5944#discussion_r361552703
 
 

 ##########
 File path: java/adapter/jdbc/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/adapter/jdbc/JdbcToArrowUtils.java
 ##########
 @@ -265,7 +265,7 @@ public static ArrowType getArrowTypeForJdbcField(JdbcFieldInfo fieldInfo, Calend
       case Types.CLOB:
         return new ArrowType.Utf8();
       case Types.DATE:

+        return new ArrowType.Date(DateUnit.DAY);

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5944#discussion_r361554765
 
 

 ##########
 File path: java/adapter/jdbc/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/adapter/jdbc/consumer/DateConsumer.java
 ##########
 @@ -101,7 +102,7 @@ public NonNullableDateConsumer(DateMilliVector vector, int index, Calendar calen
     public void consume(ResultSet resultSet) throws SQLException {
       Date date = calendar == null ? resultSet.getDate(columnIndexInResultSet) :
 
 Review comment:
   this might be legacy, but `resultSet.getDate` returns `java.sql.Date` instead of `java.util.Date`.
   Seems like there might've been some implicit conversion where we don't want underneath?

     public void consume(ResultSet resultSet) throws SQLException {
       Date date = calendar == null ? resultSet.getDate(columnIndexInResultSet) :

emkornfield commented on pull request #5944: ARROW-7301: [Java] Sql type DATE should correspond to DateDayVector
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5944#discussion_r365113601
 
 

 ##########
 File path: java/adapter/jdbc/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/adapter/jdbc/consumer/DateConsumer.java
 ##########
 @@ -69,7 +70,7 @@ public void consume(ResultSet resultSet) throws SQLException {
       Date date = calendar == null ? resultSet.getDate(columnIndexInResultSet) :
           resultSet.getDate(columnIndexInResultSet, calendar);
       if (!resultSet.wasNull()) {
-        vector.setSafe(currentIndex, date.getTime());
+        vector.setSafe(currentIndex, (int) (date.getTime() / DateDayVector.MILLIS_PER_DAY));
 
 Review comment:
   use TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS.toDays()?

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5944#discussion_r365113896
 
 

 ##########
 File path: java/adapter/jdbc/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/adapter/jdbc/consumer/DateConsumer.java
 ##########
 @@ -101,7 +102,7 @@ public NonNullableDateConsumer(DateMilliVector vector, int index, Calendar calen
     public void consume(ResultSet resultSet) throws SQLException {
       Date date = calendar == null ? resultSet.getDate(columnIndexInResultSet) :
           resultSet.getDate(columnIndexInResultSet, calendar);
-      vector.setSafe(currentIndex, date.getTime());
+      vector.setSafe(currentIndex, (int) (date.getTime() / DateDayVector.MILLIS_PER_DAY));
 
 Review comment:
   are SQL dates guaranteed to have the same range as DateDayVector? (i.e. should you check for overflow?)

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
According to SQL convertion, sql type DATE should correspond to a format of YYYY-MM-DD, without the components for hour/minute/second/millis

Therefore, JDBC type DATE should correspond to DateDayVector, with a type width of 4, instead of 8.
fields.summary: [Java] Sql type DATE should correspond to DateDayVector
